subject: linear_algebra
title: Gauss-Jordan Elimination: A Powerful Tool
contentHtml:
Gauss-Jordan elimination is a method for solving systems of linear equations that yields a unique solution in reduced row echelon form (RREF). This concept matters because it provides a systematic way to find the inverse of a matrix, which has numerous applications in machine learning and artificial intelligence.

Imagine you have a system of linear equations represented by a matrix. Gauss-Jordan elimination is like using a magic eraser to remove all the unnecessary rows and columns, leaving you with a simplified matrix that reveals its underlying structure.
intuition: Gauss-Jordan elimination is a way to simplify a matrix by eliminating variables and revealing its underlying structure, making it easier to find the inverse or solve systems of linear equations.
realWorldApplications: Finding the inverse of a matrix is crucial in neural networks for backpropagation
commonMistakes: Failing to check if the resulting matrix is in RREF
Not recognizing when a matrix has no inverse

subject: linear_algebra
title: Gauss-Jordan Elimination
contentHtml:
Gauss-Jordan elimination is a powerful technique to transform a system of linear equations into its reduced row echelon form (RREF). This process allows us to efficiently solve systems, find the inverse of a matrix, and even determine the uniqueness of solutions.

By applying a series of elementary row operations, we can systematically eliminate variables until the RREF is reached. This approach provides a clear and concise way to analyze and solve linear systems.
name: Row Echelon Form
intuition: Gauss-Jordan elimination is like solving a puzzle, where we systematically eliminate variables until the solution becomes clear. This process provides a unique perspective on linear systems and their solutions.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, Gaussian elimination is used in algorithms such as principal component analysis (PCA) and singular value decomposition (SVD).
commonMistakes: Failing to recognize that row operations preserve the solution set of the system.

statementHtml: Given a system of linear equations Ax = b, use Gauss-Jordan elimination to find the reduced row echelon form (RREF) and determine if it is unique.
hints: Start by performing elementary row operations on A until you reach RREF.
Check if the resulting matrix has a pivot in each column. If not, there may be multiple solutions or no solution at all.
If the RREF is unique, can you use it to find the inverse of A?
solutionHtml:
To solve this problem, we will perform Gauss-Jordan elimination on the matrix A.

  • Perform elementary row operations until reaching RREF:
    • \[ \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{bmatrix} \]\[ \Rightarrow \] \[\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\]
  • Check for uniqueness:
    • \[ \text{Unique RREF} \Rightarrow \text{Inverse exists} \]
",
answerShort: The reduced row echelon form is unique, and the inverse of A can be found." },

statementHtml: Given a system of linear equations Ax = b, use Gauss-Jordan elimination to find the reduced row echelon form (RREF) and determine if it is unique.
hints: Start by performing elementary row operations on A until you reach RREF.
Check if any rows become all zeros during the process. If so, eliminate those rows.
When you're done, check if the resulting matrix has a pivot in each column.
solutionHtml:
Let's work through an example:

A = \[\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \\ 5 & 6 \end{bmatrix}\]

We'll perform the following row operations:

  • \(R_2 \leftarrow R_2 - 3R_1\)
  • \(R_3 \leftarrow R_3 - 5R_1\)

This gives us:

A = \[\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 2 \\ 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\]

Now we can eliminate the second row, since it's all zeros:

A = \[\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\]

This is our RREF. Since each column has a pivot (the leading entry), we know the matrix is in unique form.

",
answerShort: The reduced row echelon form of A is unique." },

contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll demonstrate how to solve a system of linear equations using Gauss-Jordan elimination.

problem.statementHtml:
Solve the following system of linear equations:

  • 2x + y - z = 1
  • x - 3y + 2z = -2
  • 4x + 2y + z = 3
hints: Start by applying the same operations to each row
problem.solutionHtml:
To solve this system, we'll use Gauss-Jordan elimination. Here are the steps:

  1. Apply the same operation to each row: \frac{1}{2} \cdot R_1
  2. Eliminate y from the second equation by subtracting 3 times R1 from R2:R_2 - 3R_1
  3. Eliminate z from the third equation by adding R1 to R3:R_3 + R_1
  4. Now, we can read off the solution: x = 1, y = 0, and z = 2.

problem.statementHtml:
Solve the following system of linear equations:

\[\begin{align*} 2x_1 + x_2 &= 3, \\ x_1 - 2x_2 &= -4. \end{align*}\]
hints: Start by applying row operations to the augmented matrix
problem.solutionHtml:
To solve this system, we'll use Gauss-Jordan elimination. Here are the steps:

  • Step 1: Swap rows 1 and 2 to make the coefficient of \(x_1\) in the second equation positive.
    • \[\begin{align*} &\swap{1,2} \\ \end{align*}\]
  • Step 2: Add -2 times row 1 to row 2 to make the coefficient of \(x_2\) in the second equation zero.
    • \[\begin{align*} &-2R_1 + R_2 \\ \end{align*}\]
  • Step 3: Add row 1 to row 2 to make the constant term in the second equation positive.
    • \[\begin{align*} &R_1 + R_2 \\ \end{align*}\]
  • Step 4: Divide row 2 by -1 to get a positive coefficient for \(x_2\).
    • \[\begin{align*} &-R_2 \\ \end{align*}\]
